title.narrative: F.a: Supporting a Stronger Role for Women in Peace Processes

description.narrative: The continuing under representation of women and their views in peacemaking, and the persistent low capacity and readiness amongst peacemaking actors to understand and use gendered approaches in conflict analysis, conflict resolution and peacebuilding proc esses to be a major weaknesses in the global effort to support and sustain quality peace processes. This project aims to capitalize on CMI?s position as one of the main private diplomacy actors in peacemaking to enable cross-fertilization between the NGO, academic, policy and institutional actors on how to put the ?gender peace and security? and inclusion agendas into play in the best interests of peace processes. It will also stress a ?cutting edge? aspect of trying to bring new thinking and approaches to an area that many practitioners have seen as ?difficult? and driven more by values and norms than by political imperatives. Through strategic partnerships with key actors such as UN DPA and PRIO for the high level seminar on gender and mediation, or region al and subregional organisations (for example, OSCE, AU or ECCAS) building gender intelligent mediation capacity within its focus on the principle of subsidiarity in mediation, and by building a focus on the role of women in parliaments and political parti es as regards conflict resolution, CMI will enhance its ability to convene the most important, involved actors and provide them with state of the art practical knowledge, experience and enhanced networks to equip them and their teams for the contextual cha llenges of real mediation and peace process support situations.
